CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 1, 1971, pg. 21, reads: "To Cite Famous Sculptor Amidst Fashions, Fantasy - Genius at Wirk [Work] - Dr. Selma H. Burke, whose artistic fingers fashion plaster, wood, marble, granite, alabaster and limestone into authentic life-size replicas of famous personalities or precious ornaments, is pictured putting the finishing touches on her latest creation. Many of her pieces are on exhibit at the Selma S. Burke Art Center, 6118 Penn Circle South, East Liberty. - Harris Photo."Cutline of related image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 25, 1975, pg. 10, reads: "Dr. Selma Burke...artist at work." Accompanying article reads: "Carnegie Institute Museum Of Art Presents Selma Burke Sculpture - The Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute is presenting an exhibition of the work of Pittsburgh sculptor Selma Burke.  It began Friday, Jan. 17 and is extending through Sunday, Feb. 9.  Born in Mooresville, N. C., Selma Burke graduated from Columbia University in 1941, where her major interest was art, and she received a doctorate in Pedagogy from Teemers University, Charlotte, N. C.  She has studied sculpture under Reis, Malderelli [Maldarelli], Cornahani in New York, Mailloc in Paris and ceramics under Povolney in Vienna.  Actively involved in education throughout her life, she organized and directed the Greenwich Art School and served as an instructor at the Harlem Art Center in New York.  She was a consultant to the A. W. Mellon Foundation in Pittsburgh.. She is presently a member of the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, Executive Director of the Selma Burke Art Center in Pittsburgh and works with the Pittsburgh Bard of Education through the Division of Education at Carnegie Institute.  She is Chairman of the Selma Burke Sculpture Award which is presented to students accomplished in painting and sculpture.  Selma Burke, who sculpts in a wide range of media and whose work has been termed 'classical' in concept, has exhibited at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and in various city and university museums throughout the United States and Europe.  One-man exhibitions of the artist's work have been held at the Carlen Galleries, Philadelphia and at the Modernage Gallery and Artists Gallery, New York.  Sculpture by Selma Burke may be viewed in first floor gallery 21 Tuesday through Sunday from 10 until 5.  The Museum is closed Mondays."
